description: Inherited from Middle English *clemmen, *clammen, from Old English clemman, clæmman (“to press, surround”), from Proto-West Germanic *klammjan (“to squeeze”).
Cognate with Dutch klemmen (“to jam, pinch, stick”), German klemmen (“to jam, clamp; to be stuck, stick [to a surface]”).

verbs.description: clem (third-person singular simple present clems, present participle clemming, simple past and past participle clemmed)

entries.meaning: (UK, dialect, transitive or intransitive) To be hungry; starve.
examples: " […]  Here he's back home again, and without work, and without a penny, and thou knows t' little one and I were pretty well clemmed to death when thou got us a bit o' bread and meat last night. We were that!"

description: Possibly from clementine, a small round citrus fruit.

verbs.description: clem (third-person singular simple present clems, present participle clemming, simple past and past participle clemmed)
